Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Engineering Human Capital in Technology Adoption and Discovery: Impact on Japans Industrialization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration: Human capital is a critical ingredient in the discovery of innovations and adoption of technology, but what type of human capital is most important for such activities, and what are the roles of higher-order technical skills in particular, remain largely unexplored. Japan started its transition to modernity in the late 1870s by building an engineering education system from scratch. It searched for a way to allocate newly minted engineering cadres to the right places given its economic and societal needs, all while facing several practical constraints. This project will conduct an in-depth theoretical and empirical investigation of the process of formation of engineering human capital in late 19th century and early 20th century Japan, and the mechanisms that allocated that human capital. The team will construct and employ a detailed database based on alumni yearbooks to follow the census of degreed Japanese engineers through their careers. In so doing, they will identify work networks and their effects, linking these to the performance of firms, industries, and regions. The project will also investigate how educated engineers contributed to socially beneficial discovery by matching the constructed database to inventors’ names in Japan Patent Office data. Barriers to technology adoption represent a main obstacle to economic development, but we still have little systematic knowledge of the roles performed by the key actor, the engineer. This project examines the process and effects of developing an educated engineering workforce. In-depth examination of the underlying processes and mechanisms will inform contemporary theoretical, policy, and managerial discourse, including valuable lessons for U.S. policymakers. It will also have implications for the global fight against poverty and economic stagnation. <br/><br/>This project will explore various issues related to technology discovery and adoption, as well as firm and regional competitiveness, by focusing on the availability and allocation of higher-end technical skills embodied in educated engineers. This will form a richer picture of the sources of industrial and social development. It will also highlight the importance of network effects and the role played by competitive market allocative mechanism. This project, by developing and deploying for quantitative analyses a unique trove of alumni lists and other archival sources in Japan, will make an important contribution to understanding key issues tied to technology adoption, growth, and development. Studying the interactions among technological opportunity, human capital formation, market demand, and institutional rules is a promising way to better understand how nations can both take advantage of existing advanced technologies and develop new ones. Elucidating engineering human capital’s role in the context of late 19th-early 20th century Japan (the first modern industrial economy to establish itself outside of Western Europe and its North American and Australian offshoots) will not just be novel intellectually but will also inform debates about promoting technology adoption and scientific discovery in today’s developing countries. The project will also make publicly available a comprehensive decades-long dataset on engineers, their employers, and networks. The team will broadly disseminate findings through presentations in seminars and conferences as well as through academic publications. The project will also help train graduate students as research assistants and as coauthors on academic papers and will enhance collaboration with Japanese universities and individual scholars through joint work. The database will be made available so others can use it to examine and build additional theories and insights.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Barriers to technology adoption represent a main obstacle to economic development, but we still have little systematic knowledge of the roles performed by the key actor, the engineer. Japan’s industrialization, whose remarkable success prompted Robert E. Lucas to place it in its own category in his account of economic growth since the Industrial Revolution, presents a great case study to examine the mechanisms that created and allocated high-level, educated engineering human capital, and to elucidate its role in the discovery of innovations and adoption of technology. In this project, we conducted an in-depth empirical investigation of the process of formation of science and engineering human capital in late 19th century and early 20th century Japan, the key role it played in the country’s industrialization and considered the implications for modern-day developing countries and economic and management research and policy-making in general.

The project commenced with data development, during which we immersed ourselves in the archival materials containing detailed, high-quality historical data and constructed a unique panel database encompassing the census of all Imperial university-educated scientists and engineers from the inception of the higher technical education system in Japan in the 1870s and until the 1920 graduation cohorts. The work involved digitizing and processing university alumni yearbooks, identifying science and engineering graduates, followed by manually inputting the names of their employers and addresses throughout post-graduation careers, until 1940. The names and addresses from this database were matched to the patent data available from the Japan Patent Office (JPO) to identify inventors––science and engineering graduates from Japan’s Imperial Universities who were assignees on at least one patent registered in the JPO. English transliterations of the Japanese names were used to match them with the Google patent data to identify those who patented globally. The outcome of this stage was the database consisting of over 6,900 graduates from Imperial Universities’ science and engineering departments, among them 1,360 inventors and 198 global inventors.

 

The second stage of the project involved manually disambiguating employer names to identify specific firms, government organizations and academic and research institutions they represented. We used various Japanese archival data, such as Business Archives Online, published company histories, and other sources to collect and digitize the data on firm performance (balance sheets, executive boards’ membership, major shareholders), aiming to link the employment of educated scientists and engineers to the growth of firms and industries. Using Imperial Universities’ yearbooks, we also digitized the curricula and names of the faculty who taught at science and engineering departments to trace the evolution of the higher science and engineering education systems and to identify teacher-student connections. We also extended our database to include graduates from Technical Colleges (second-tier institutions providing higher engineering education).

 

In the third phase of the project, armed with the databases above and having disambiguated the employer names, we traced and examined scientists’ and engineers’ careers in industry, academia, and government seeking answers to the following overarching questions. First, how did the expansion of a country’s higher technical education system affect the relationship between engineering human capital and industrial and economic development? Second, what was the role of engineers as a special type of human capital input in the production process, discovery of new innovations, and how did it change at different stages of development? Third, how did mobility and career choices of engineers change with the development of specialized knowledge, and how did they in turn affect the development of such knowledge and its applications? The tangible outcomes include but are not limited to: (1) working paper “Science and Engineering Education and Invention in Japan’s Industrialization” (peer-reviewed and presented at the NBER Japan Project in Tokyo in December 2021); (2) the paper “Resource Allocation and Growth Strategies in a Multi-Plant Firm” (peer-reviewed and forthcoming in the Strategic Management Journal), (3) PhD Dissertation Proposal and job market paper by Shotaro Yamaguchi (graduate student funded by the grant) entitled “Individual Mobility and Firm Reallocation: Scientists and Engineers during Japan’s Industrialization.” 

Japan’s ascension from a poor backward economy to a modern industrial nation stands out as the first such case outside of Western Europe and its offshoots. This ascension would not have been possible without educated engineering talent. The issues like those Japan faced in that era are enduring and timeless. Today, for example, there is a critical need to develop new, specialized, high-level human capital for the fourth industrial revolution––the rapid transformation of existing industries based on machine learning, artificial intelligence, and 3-D printing. We expect that our in-depth examination of the underlying processes and mechanisms will inform contemporary theoretical, policy, and managerial discourse, including valuable lessons for U.S. policymakers. It will also have implications for the global fight against poverty. We also plan to provide open access to our database for the benefit of the larger research community.
